[h1] Love Overwatch. Hate Blizzard. (Only SuitLizards. Exclude the Actual Devs/Workers) [/h1]

The first banner I got after connecting my Blizzard account had a big button to the in-game shop. I expect a game to let me play and have fun when I walk into it; not to put up a store to drain my wallet and tell me to grind a BattlePass.

The only dopamine hit I got after opening the game was from the repetitive Achievement sfx by Steam Overlay.

---

I've always loved the core game ever since its initial release. It's nothing short of depressing to see such a title fall because of Blizzard's continued intentional failures.
It's barely enjoyable for me to play this game anymore. The hours I pour into this game only come from me partying up with friends (who are, somehow, still ignorant to the poor choices made by Blizzard with regards to design and monetization). Also because, as stated earlier, I still love the core game.

---

Stuff written under here are what I assume to be true. But I can't be sure if I'm right. So feel free to tell me how delusional and misleading I am.

A couple months or so before OW2's release, I spotted a sale on OW that gave some extra skins as a bonus. I seriously considered buying it because of the promise that was delivered alongside. The promise of OW2's huge PVE mode and also the promise of keeping OW alive for those who want to continue playing it.
Both those promises were broken.

I could continue my rant for a review but this is long enough already.
There are some other reviews that cover actual issues with gameplay in-depth. Do give them a read.

---

TL;DR
I would much prefer someone spend their time and money on games that respect you as a player who makes a purchase that is appropriately priced for the kind of work put into it.
Overwatch2 is not one of those games.
I still love the game, but cannot recommend you spend your precious time and money on it.
I have been and will be a Overwatch player ever since was made (2016) and based on my experience I say this game is one of the best in the world.

I don't really know how to begin. I've played Overwatch for well over 3,000 hours now, and when it came to Steam I knew I had to review it here, to which unfortunately I think the course has been run.

Overwatch itself being the hero-arena shooter allows for some serious strategy, and that's what Jeff would have done before the game spiraled into Overwatch 2. I'm sorry, I can't support what they've done since releasing this game.

Constant server problems with tracking titles/stats/login etc, monetizing EVERYTHING, catering to it's new audience rather than anyone who played before. I miss when they cared about this game. This update, while a step in the right direction, took another step back when charging $15 for the Invasion content. Imagine paying for Overwatch 1, then Overwatch 2 comes out and is now free, what would you think Overwatch 1 players would get? At least the things Overwatch 2 promised! After PVE was cut, I knew the door was shut for Overwatch.

Ultimately, the core gameplay is far worse as 5v5 versus 6v6, but it's Overwatch so it'll be a good time for a while, and with friends even more, but the developers really sunk this titan deep into the ground.

Well, sadly few things have changed since I last tried it on b.net.

There are some upsides to Overwatch 2. Among it are a cadre of [b]superbly[/b] well-crafted heroes you can play, down to right the newest ones. Their visuals, their animations, and in particular their sound- and voice-work are [b]phenomenal[/b]. Most of the maps are also beautifully done, really bringing out the work done with the characters.

Further, the core gameplay loop of the game modes is really well thought out, in particular OW's spin on payload where you first have to capture the payload to start pushing it is good.

However, the game is marred by two extremely big issues.

First, and probably well-known at this point, is the [b]extreme[/b] level of microtransactions - and calling them that is questionable considering skins cost up to 20€ a piece and even individual voicelines cost you 1-3€ - that pervades the entire design. Everything is built to funnel you towards spending money, the game has essentially switched design-focus from a game with a store to now being a store that just happens to have a game attached. I cannot overstate just [b]how[/b] bad this feels compared to the old paid-for game that was Overwatch 1. Even ignoring the comparison however, the new store-centric design forces Blizzard to make more and more and more vivid and outrageous skins and visuals, which in turn takes a [b]huge[/b] chunk out of the superb visual design I mentioned above.

Second, they still have not even scratched the surface of the rebalancing needed after the removal of a second tank and the reduction from 6v6 to 5v5 in the switch-over to Overwatch 2. Sure, many elements work. But balance is all over the place, and importantly significantly worse compared to the previous game outside of eSports situations, and even there just barely better. It's a shame, because there [b]are[/b] good ideas in there, but as expected these come with a need to go back to the drawing board with [b]all[/b] heroes, doing sweeping rebalances all-over, and Blizzard has so fare only made small~moderate reworks and comparatively minor adjustments. Which were good, don't get me wrong, but as said before, it barely scratches the surface of what is needed.

So, overall, sadly I still cannot recommend the game at all. I loved Overwatch 1, I enjoyed some of the ideas behind Overwatch 2, but the game just doesn't feel like something remotely release-ready. Feels like an early-ish beta.

This review is being typed by someone who has played the game since release day May 3rd, 2016. Overwatch 2™, when you strip away any controversies, is a fantastic Free-to-Play hero shooter. Looking at the game through the eyes of a brand new player, there's a good chance that you will enjoy your time with the game! You may fall in love with the art style or maybe heroes and their backgrounds. The cast of heroes is expansive and there is a hero for everyone! There is a good reason why the original title won 2016s Game of the Year! You will undoubtly come across alot of hate for the game which for all intent and purposes is completely justified!

Lets talk about some of that hate. Despite Overwatch 2™ being a well-polished game, there are a bunch of issues that the community has with its current state. For starters, a whole list of broken promises. Overwatch 2™ was originally supposed to be this highly replayable PvE with hero customization that you could sink hours and hours into. The game was supposed to be this complete story package. Unfortunately that vision was not able to be met. The story mode component has now been shoehorned into the predatory monetization model that was introduced with the converstion of the original Overwatch™ into Overwatch 2™ and will be drip-fed over the course of the games lifecycle. Speaking of the monetization model, expect to be met with battle passes and $20+ 'bundles' when you open up the 'Shop' tab on the main menu. There is currently no way to earn Premium currency (the currency to purchase battle passes and shop skins). The original Overwatch™ handled monetization a bit differently. The original utilized 'loot boxes'. This system wasn't too bad though! You would earn a box everytime you leveled up. You also had a chance to receive credits that could be saved up to purchase any skin in the game! Alot of old players are used to this system. It allowed these players to own every cosmetic in the game.

Moving on, another point of contention is the removal of a handful of original Overwatch™ features. Some examples would include account progression, post match voting system, a PTR server for testing new and upcoming changes/heroes, 'On fire' system (recently added back via Overwatch 2™s season 5), and many more features. The community hopes that most, if not, all of these systems will return in future updates to the game.

In conclusion, Overwatch 2™ is a fantasic and addictive game that will keep you entertained for hours on end. If you are brand new to this game and have never played it before, I highly recommend downloading it and giving it a shot!
